questions.question_text: A penetration tester has run multiple vulnerability scans against a target system. Which of the following would be unique to a credentialed scan?

discussion.content: Answer B. Remember that a credentialed scan allow you to check configuration of the system in order to validate certain vulnerabilities findings.

comments.content:
however, most of the time it is best to run a credentialed scan against a target to get a full picture of the attack surface. An authenticated scan requires you to provide the scanner with a set of credentials that have root-level access to the system. The reason for this is that the scanner actually logs in to the target via SSH or some other mechanism. It then runs commands like netstat to gather information from inside the host. Many of the commands that the scanner runs require root-level access to be able to gather the correct information from the system.

Figure 3-41 shows the netstat command run by a non-privileged user and then run again by a root user. You can see that the output is different for the different user-level permissions. Specifically, notice that when running as the user ron, the PID/Program name is not available, and when running as the user root, that information is displayed.
I agree, B makes the most sense to me.

discussion.content: bbbbbbbbb

Selected Answer: B
looks good to me

Selected Answer: B
Answer is B

Selected Answer: B
The authenticated scans provide more details so I'd say B

Answer B

Pentest just exploit not vulnerability scanner

Answer A. Credentialed Scanning - Delegate (and revoke) credentials appropriately. Credentialed scanning entails conducting a vulnerability assessment...
Debunk the bandwidth myth. By virtue of its increased access, credentialed scanning's effectiveness in discovering...
B is the correct answer, credential scans give you the most insight to configs
A: Credential-based vulnerability assessment, which make use of the admin account, do a more thorough check by looking for problems that cannot be seen from the network.

comments.content: I do not believe you are looking at this correctly.... A credentialed scan provides exploits and a non-credentialed scan does not? Thats a negative.... Credentialed scan will give better insight into configurations due to increased privilege.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
looks good to me

The answer is A & B. In this scenario, the tester is asked to conduct Nmap scans for OS fingerprinting from a defined list of IP addresses saved to a text file. The following switches will yield the desired results/objective: 
-O = Remote OS detection using TCP/IP stack fingerprinting 
-iL = Scans targets from a file
It was on the exam
Repeated question, but it was answered wrong. The answer here is correct.
Yeah, is AB

questions.question_text: A penetration tester has been asked to conduct OS fingering with Nmap using a company-provided text file that contains a list of IP addresses. Which of the following are needed to conduct this scan? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: I would go with B. Out of all the options this one would be the easiest to spot, especially if there is a user creation process in place.

comments.content: Agreed

agreed. C might not be easy to spot, especially if its already a known service, this would require further investigation like checking the command/executable the service is calling. This is coming from a support perspective that deals with these issues everyday. :)
B? Why?

discussion.content: Answer B
cccccccccc

Selected Answer: B
looks good to me

Its got to be B. My company has systems in place so that ANY new domain user account created is alarmed and reviewed. The "Known" password part just means the hacker knows the password. Anyone saying "But sir, Local Account". The answer specifically states new *domain* user. Not a good question, but B is by far the easiest to detect with alerts in place.

comments.content:
Domain users - anybody who has a user account and has authenticated within the domain. Their level of rights in the domain could be at any level granted to them.

Domain Administrators - Users granted "God-Like" authority within the domain to access and modify practically anything and everything.

discussion.content: Remeber its not saying Domain Admin, instead it says Domain User. Meaning any account with any level of privilege's. Identifying this would be difficult, especially if his shell on a target host hasnt been detected yet, pointing towards a weak blue team. With that said id say the answer is Modifying a "KNOWN" boot time service. As this is probably the only thing they would be aware of.

I can see B, youre jacking with a DC if you're creating a new domain account. Likely the security team will have alerts set up on a DC to watch for new user accounts. Unless the security team has finely tuned tools, they wont capture a local machine having a modification, especially if the pentester is using an admin account. DC logs are harder to erase and easier to see than local machine

My 2cents:
Is not A for sure. Is not B because that would be stupid, think about it what is the difference between creating a new domain user with a known password vs. creating a new domain user with an unknown password???? Is not D because that makes you thing about some sort of bruteforce but you are already in, so the most that is valid to me would be C.
B. would be valid if it was like "Create a new domain user"

Hello guys! A friend of mine told me that the correct answer was D, and yes, I know, I was TF?! And he told me that you can easily detect them with a simple script, this is one of the software that he has used in the past.

https://logrhythm.com/blog/clear-text-passwords-use-case/

"Using a simple Analyze query on NetMon, you can detect clear text passwords sent over HTTP."

What are your thoughts?

comments.content: Your friend is probably right but I doubt that's the answer comptia wants.

discussion.content:
B. Creation of a new user account is a tried-and-true method for retaining access to a system.
In well-managed and monitored environments, adding an account is likely to be caught and
result in an alarm, but in many environments creation of a local user account on a system
may allow ongoing access to the system, device, or application.

Question: MOST easily ***detected***

Scripting a callback (reverse shell) on reboot would be detectable through network monitoring, most SIEMs when checking for unusual but repeated outbound network connection (splunk / elk etc)

I was tending to option C but I think B is correct. C may be detectable by an AV suite, but maybe not and the use of 'boot time' would probably suggest that they want you to think root kit. Which they want you to think is difficult to detect. Option B can be spotted by good procedures and not rely on technology.

None of these are great answers. If the domain had 10 people, definitively B. In a domain with thousands of users, it would be hard to track this down unless some sort of alert was generated when a new user was created. If you just create a Steve Smith and dump him in an OU with 200 people, no one will know. C seems like the more obvious choice but maybe that was intentional to be misleading. I have no answer, merely conjecture.

comments.content: creation of account usually have been logged. just ask admins if that user should have been created at that time.
It's not asking which is the easiest to prevent, it's asking which is the easiest to detect.
But then there are no rules created on IDS/IPS/FW to detect that Zero Day attack, hence I wouldn't say that's the most detectable one. Actually Zero days go unnoticed sometimes for months at a time.
A Zero Day exploit may not have patches to address it yet. Hence, Day Zero.

TF? It's asking which hacker's method of maintaining persistence is most easily discovered by the blue team... At first glance you want to say create an account...but with 100s of accounts, an additional J.Smith may go UN-noticed. Moreso than getting a service to call back? A truly subjective question.
yes, but if you have a system that monitors AD account creation, this would be easy. just ask the administrator if there should be a newly created account that time.
zerodays don't have patches available. The recent exchange vulnerability existed for 10 years before it was patched.

discussion.content: Answer A. This is the most easy way because you can prevent it by applying the last patches of the system.

choices.C: Modify a known boot time service to instantiate a call back.
choices.D: Obtain cleartext credentials of the compromised user.
choices.B: Create a new domain user with a known password.

questions.question_text: After establishing a shell on a target system, Joe, a penetration tester is aware that his actions have not been detected. He now wants to maintain persistent access to the machine. Which of the following methods would be MOST easily detected?

discussion.content: Agreed. Although I think of system hardening as more patching of vulnerabilities or tighter configurations/security. They need to implement an AntiSpam service or device to catch phony links in emails. C might loosely work to fit that definition but D is the better option. Not really solving the problem of inept users though, just making it harder for the attacker by using MFA.

Selected Answer: D
looks good to me

Selected Answer: D
2FA makes the most sense.
Only way of making sure that, irrespective of what happens with password, access to the eMail system is still not possible would be MFA? Would say D.

comments.content: Eh not a tricky question. Like who__cares mentioned, all of the options can be broken without MFA. MFA is the strongest option here. I dont care you have my password if you dont have my phone or fingerprint, you're not getting into my account or email account

Not really! Harden mail all you want, I will still log right in if you send me your passwords! I understand your thought process, but if hardening mail stopped all phishing, everyone would have done it 15 years ago! 2FA will protect you when a dummy gives his/her passwd, though we need the caveat that it shouldnt be an emailed option!(Since attacker will likely have the passwd to read the email sent to the dummy! Make the 2FA text a code to the dummy's phone!!

Agree. Although based on the question is talking about credentials to log on email accounts, perhaps the pentester realized how many phishing attempts there were. Then, he/she would recommend C. Email system hardening, due to it's cheaper and easier to implement than 2FA. 
By hardening your email you make it much harder for fraudulent email being sent using your domain name. When implemented correctly this should also help with deliverability, thus reducing the changes of your email being flagged as spam.

2FA would eliminate this attack vector, while 'Email system hardening' would reduce it. So it's another tricky question.
C. will not even fix the problem assuming the social engineering works. MFA is the only reasonable answer.

discussion.content: D seems to be the best answer however I think that C could also be a viable answer.

The consultant is given credentials to log on to various employees email accounts. Given the findings, which of the following should the consultant recommend be implemented?

questions.question_text: A penetration tester wants to check manually if a `ghost` vulnerability exists in a system. Which of the following methods is the correct way to validate the vulnerability?

choices.C: Download the GHOST file to a Linux system and compile gcc -o GHOST GHOST.c test i: ./GHOST
choices.D: Download the GHOST file to a Windows system and compile gcc -o GHOST test i: ./GHOST
choices.B: Download the GHOST file to a Windows system and compile gcc -o GHOST GHOST.c test i: ./GHOST
choices.A: Download the GHOST file to a Linux system and compile gcc -o GHOST test i: ./GHOST
